name: CircuitBreaker
title: @CircuitBreaker for Fault Tolerance
description: Build a fault tolerant microservice ...

steps.name: Intro
steps.title: Introduction
description: It is important to build microservices to be fault tolerant for resilience against failure. Fault tolerance is about using different strategies to ensure reduced impact and continued operation of services in the event of failure. MicroProfile makes this very simple with their fault tolerance feature.
In this guide, we will introduce the circuit breaker and fallback concepts and show how to implement them using the MicroProfile fault tolerance feature.
instruction:
To get started, add the mpFaultTolerance-1.0 feature to your server.xml.
<featureManager>
	<feature>mpFaultTolerance-1.0</feature>
</featureManager>

steps.name: Background
steps.title: Background Concepts
description: We will be using MicroProfile's CircuitBreaker and Fallback policies for our fault tolerance implementation.
CircuitBreaker allows us to fail fast by automatically failing executions to prevent system overload, indefinite wait, or client timeout.
Fallback provides an alternate solution for the failed execution.
Microservice is an architecture that structures an application loosely from other services so it is independent and modular.

steps.name: CircuitBreaker
steps.title: Circuit Breaker
description: The circuit breaker design pattern allows your microservice to fail immediately to prevent repeated executions that are likely to fail.

The software circuit breaker operates much like an electrical circuit breaker. A closed circuit represents a fully functional system, and an open circuit represents an incomplete system. In the event of failure, the circuit breaker triggers to open the circuit, removing the point of failure from the system.

In a software circuit breaker, there is an additional half-open state. Once the circuit is opened, it will periodically transition to the half-open state, where it will check if the failed component is restored and close the circuit once it is considered safe and functional.

steps.name: Fallback
steps.title: Fallback
description: A fallback service runs when the main service fails. When used in conjunction with other fault tolerant design patterns, a fallback can provide graceful failure or continued or partial operation of the original service.

In our example, we will be using a fallback with a circuit breaker. When the main service fails and triggers the circuit breaker to open the circuit, subsequent requests for the service will be routed to the fallback service until the main service is restored.

steps.name: Scenario
steps.title: Example: Bank Scenario
description: Imagine that your online banking application has many different microservices:

• a service for checking your balance
  • a service for transferring money
  • a service for depositing money
  • a balance snapshot service used as a backup of data
On the next step, you will try to check your balance on the bank's website.

steps.name: AfterAddCircuitBreakerAnnotation
steps.title: Add @CircuitBreaker Annotation
description: Let us add a default @CircuitBreaker policy to the Check Balance microservice.
instruction:
Add the @CircuitBreaker annotation on line 6, above the Check Balance service, or click:
@CircuitBreaker()
Click the Save button on the upper left of the editor menu pane.

steps.name: ConfigureFailureThresholdParams
steps.title: Configure Failure Threshold
description: The CircuitBreaker policy opens the circuit when sufficient calls to the microservice fail. The policy determines the failure threshold by looking at the latest requests to the service, also known as a rolling window. You can modify this failure threshold by using these two parameters:
• requestVolumeThreshold: The size of the rolling window used to determine the failure threshold. The default is 20.
• failureRatio: The minimum failure ratio in the rolling window to trigger the circuit breaker. The default is 0.5.

The failureRatio is used in conjunction with the requestVolumeThreshold to determine when the circuit will trip. For example, if the requestVolumeThreshold is 20 and the failureRatio is 0.5, 10 failures in a rolling window of 20 requests will trigger the circuit to open.
instruction:
Change the @CircuitBreaker annotation on line 7 to, or click: @CircuitBreaker(requestVolumeThreshold=8, failureRatio=0.25)
Click the Save button on the upper left of the editor menu pane.
Click on the refresh in the browser below to see the first Check Balance call fail in the closed circuit state.
Click on the refresh again in the browser to see the second fail call changes the circuit to open state.

content.content:
Change the default @CircuitBreaker annotation to
@CircuitBreaker(requestVolumeThreshold=8,
failureRatio=0.25)
Click the save button.
Click on the refresh button in the browser below.
Click on the refresh button again in the browser.

steps.name: ConfigureDelayParams
steps.title: Configure Delay
description: By default, the circuit will remain open for 5000 ms. During this period, all requests to the main service will be blocked and will fail immediately. At the end of this period, the circuit will transition to the half-open state and check if the main service is healthy. This time period can be configured with the delay parameter.
• delay: The delay in milliseconds after the circuit opens until checking the main service's availability.
instruction:
Change the @CircuitBreaker annotation on line 7 to, or click: @CircuitBreaker(requestVolumeThreshold=8, failureRatio=0.25, delay=3000)
Click the Save button.
Click on the Refresh button in the browser below to see how the above annotation affects the Check Balance call.

steps.name: ConfigureSuccessThresholdParams
steps.title: Configure Success Threshold
description: When the circuit is half-open, requests to the microservice are allowed through. However, if a request should fail while the circuit is half-open, the request will immediately fail and the circuit will return to an open state. Otherwise, if a specified number of consecutive requests succeed, the microservice is deemed healthy and the circuit will close.
The default number of consecutive successes needed is 1, and can be adjusted with the successThreshold parameter.
• successThreshold: The number of consecutive successful invocations of the service required before closing the circuit.
instruction:
Change the @CircuitBreaker annotation on line 7 to, or click: @CircuitBreaker(requestVolumeThreshold=8, failureRatio=0.25, delay=3000, successThreshold=2)
Click the Save button.
Click the Refresh button in the browser below to see the first Check Balance call succeed in the half-open circuit state.
Click the Refresh button in the browser again. This second successful call meets our success threshold and closes the circuit.

steps.name: AddFallBack
steps.title: Add @Fallback Annotation
description: Using the @Fallback annotation, add a fallback method that will execute when the Check Balance microservice is down and the circuit is in an open state. Our fallback method will invoke the bank's Balance Snapshot microservice to return a cached value of the user's balance.

steps.name: fallbackService
steps.title: Check Balance with Fallback
description: When the circuit is in an open state, the bank's Check Balance microservice fails right away and the fallback service is executed. The circuit will transition to a half-open state after the specified delay.
instruction: Click on the refresh button in the browser below to see the fallback method immediately invoked when the circuit is open.

steps.name: playground
steps.title: Circuit Breaker Demo
description: Now that you have learned about circuit breakers and fallbacks, you can explore the parameters in the @CircuitBreaker annotation and see the circuit in action.
Here is a recap of the parameters:
<ul>
• requestVolumeThreshold: The size of the rolling window used to determine the failure threshold. The default is 20.
• failureRatio: The minimum failure ratio in the rolling window to trigger the circuit breaker. The default is 0.5.
• delay: The delay in milliseconds to transition to a half-open state after the circuit is open. The default is 5000ms.
• successThreshold: The number of consecutive successful invocations of the service required before closing the circuit. The default is 1.
instruction: Modify the @CircuitBreaker parameters and save the file in the editor to configure your circuit breaker.
You can simulate successful or failed requests to the microservice to see how the circuit state changes.

steps.name: WhatNext
steps.title: What's Next
steps.description: Congratulations, you have learned how to use a circuit breaker and provide a fallback to make your microservice fault tolerant.
